reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s main comparatively-optimistic pathway (partial AM-convergence + trade/compromise) by arguing that trade-enabling commitment institutions plausibly also enable coercion, making the sign of the trade story unclear without a cooperative-vs-extortion equilibrium model. That’s fairly central because the essay leans on trade as the most promising route to mostly-great futures if WAM-convergence fails, though it’s not the essay’s only claim (it also argues WAM-convergence is unlikely and remains broadly uncertain overall). The objection has moderate strength: it identifies a real under-modeled dependency (mechanism design/equilibrium selection) and pushes beyond what’s already conceded, but it doesn’t show that cooperative equilibria are unlikely or unstable—only that the essay’s net optimism is insufficiently grounded. Most statements are plausible and largely consistent with standard commitment/threat concerns, though the tight coupling (“the very institutions…also enable”) is somewhat overstated because some governance/contract designs can differentially inhibit coercion. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: Pro-trade institutions also enable extortion, leaving net benefits underdetermined without equilibrium design
